description: From Middle English coude, couthe, cuthe, from Old English cūþe, past indicative and past subjunctive form of cunnan (“to be able”) (compare related cūþ, whence English couth). The 'l' was added in the early 16th century by analogy with should and would; this was probably helped by the tendency for 'l' to be lost in those words  (and so not written, leading to shudd, wode, etc).

entries.meaning: Something that could happen, or could be the case, under different circumstances; a potentiality.

examples: Before I was blind, I could see very well.

entries.meaning: Used as a past subjunctive (contrary to fact).
examples: I think he could do it if he really wanted to.

entries.meaning: Used to politely ask for permission to do something.
Used to politely ask for someone else to do something.
Used to show the possibility that something might happen.
examples: We could rearrange the time if you like.
You could try adding more salt to the soup.

entries.meaning: (obsolete except Tyneside) past participle of can
